bycapablepeople: @stellameghie @issarae @lakeithstanfield3 ... both the writing and direction made its way from a understanding and kind heart. It can be complicated when the budget (studio) and the production are of two opposite opportunities ( sewn together for comfort) overall for the best outcomes. That being shared as my opinion.... the two main characters (+intro/sub character) tone of voice adds to their (real for real) natural demeanors in the "making the film". Both @issarae vocal pitch+ and @lakeithstanfield3 vocal flow~ forms something more than is expected, not unexpected...almost "quirky coolness" to the "t".😉 So much to take away and run with and only to celebrate a wonderful depiction of change, movement, sadness, hope, passion, discovery, disappointments, love, ..and much love. One to grow on, "I wish I was as good at love as I was at working.” I wish I didn’t leave(the) people (that I love) behind so often." JOB WELL DONE!

fancinanc: Issa you’re the first celebrity I’m writing to like I know, but I had to. Your movie did something to me last night. And on a first date. unapoligeticallyme: Dear @stellameghie & @issarae, I wanted y’all to know that #ThePhotograph resonated with me on so many levels. I was extremely emotional throughout the entire movie and I found myself crying before the characters started crying. I see myself in “Mae” and “Christine,” and I believe the pathology of Black mothers having a hard time showing love and affection to their daughters really put my own relationship with my mother in perspective. I know many other Black women can relate to feeling unloved by their mothers because their is a lack of affection and our ptsd (post traumatic slave disorder) that was created from our enslavement in this country. Then the relationship that “Christine” had with “Issac” made me realize that I might be missing out on a chance to find love with a Black man that I have been friends with for almost 20 years because of my fear of losing him and losing our friendship. Thank you for making this beautiful art piece of BLACK 💕 LOVE. This is definitely 1 of my favorite movies of all times. Thank u Issa for choosing to show Black women as our authentic beautiful selves. Also, thank u to the entire cast & crew for creating & being Black excellence. Peace & Light

jennyrod19: My hubby and I really enjoyed the movie. I think he has a crush on you now 😂
natasharollerson: The Photograph: I’m so sad to see all of the harsh criticism directed at this movie. I loved it! You know why? Because it was a normal story that could have been plucked from the everyday life of any African American household. It wasn’t about slavery, drugs, gangs, being a player, or stealing. I understand why those genres are entertaining. But, the World needs to see us just being US. Sadly, black lives need to be normalized. We need to be depicted as In love, successful, driven, positive AND HAPPY! I loved the complexity of the characters. Thank you for this unicorn of a film. 👏🏽👏🏽 @issarae

therealsaniyah_: it made you really realize a lot of things in relationships. Trying to commit. Love. Seek another ones attention, time,effort, dignity.... It was just a lot to take away from that movie and one thing I could relate to was when he told her he was leaving to london and she didn't know how to tell him how she truly felt but when they went to the concert and she was explaining to him that her love lies for him whenever his feet land. Love doesn't just leave because sometimes we may have to leave from each other but that doesn't mean call it quits. Bring back that old love, when u ask your grandparents how long they have been together and they say 30+ years. Through all them years they been thru hell and back but what thing that didn't break them nor take them away was The LOVE they had amongst each other.
